57f38f6f9a568ff4f07f5ee9112e55f5.title: Let’s Throw Some Money at Our Problems: February 2017 Check-In

8c5cf35c6e2a.bio: Tech Professional by day| Blogger of enoughwithdebt.com in my spare time. Documenting my debt journey of paying off $70K in 12 months.
8c5cf35c6e2a.name: Lewis Pike

352933fd661d.bio: I have ridiculous ideas about what is and is not appropriate.
352933fd661d.name: Nicole L

f5ac390c9ec3.bio: Rescue animals, tattoos, and constant revisions to my 5 year plan.
f5ac390c9ec3.name: JennyCons

paragraphs.name: f997
paragraphs.text: Big month guys. I got my tax return back, and my promotion finally went through (24% annual increase) and I got my retro pay back to when it should have started, 10/9/16.

paragraphs.name: b12a
paragraphs.text:
Moving Goal — $4k
February 1 — $0
February 28 — $4,000 FUNDED!

virtuals.subtitle: I am paying off a student loan at 2.625% interest, the original balance was about $50,000

9efc7397e31f.title: I didn’t work from December 21st to February 13th.

content.subtitle: I am paying off a student loan at 2.625% interest, the original balance was about $50,000

paragraphs.name: 291b
paragraphs.text: I didn’t work from December 21st to February 13th. So, the emergency fund (which I have actually named the “Laid-off Fund” as being out of work for a few months is not uncommon in my industry) was totally depleted. Sigh. Here we go again.

paragraphs.name: 105e
paragraphs.text: I am paying off a student loan at 2.625% interest, the original balance was about $50…

paragraphs.name: ed47
paragraphs.text: Feb was good. I spent a lot on little things I’d put off in Jan but needed before I-owe-$450-in-taxes-March and still moved forwards.
Vacation ($2,500 goal): Jan 17 $1,090/Feb 17 $1,140

paragraphs.name: 6eef
paragraphs.text: March Update:

paragraphs.name: c06f
paragraphs.text: My goal is to have all of my debt paid off by the end of 2017. Most of it is student loans with interest rates ranging from 2.6% to 6.80%. I didn’t get serious about paying my debt off until June of this year. I’m tired of having debt hanging around and throwing so much away per month to interest. I threw a big…

6975e5546cc.title: Pretty standard month, but things might start changing up with my partner leaving his job next…

paragraphs.name: 935a
paragraphs.text: Pretty standard month, but things might start changing up with my partner leaving his job next month (currently job hunting, but there’s a definite end date to current employment). Good news is that he’s getting packaged out, ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ news is that everything else is up in the air. We’ll just keep doing the normal stuff until I start getting nervous…

5345e4aff625.title: Look what was in today’s mail!

paragraphs.name: c8bc
paragraphs.text: Look what was in today’s mail!
On 12/1 my student loans were $99,927.

paragraphs.name: dd29
paragraphs.text: Today, they are $56,872.

paragraphs.name: a235
paragraphs.text: I don’t remember if I shared this here yet but I got a large windfall from my stepmother and my late dad last month: $40k to loans, $5k to savings, and $5k to credit card debt (related to cross country travel.) It feels good to be debt…

c8da1d4b49d8.title: Law school student loans: I always say the original amount I took out in loans was “$100k plus…

paragraphs.name: 905e
paragraphs.text: Law school student loans: I always say the original amount I took out in loans was “$100k plus” because I don’t actually know what it is, since I’ve refinanced/consolidated a couple times. Recently, I tried to do the math, and the original loan amount plus interest, when I started my repayments in 2009, might have been around $120,000??? Anyway….

content.subtitle: For the first time ever though, I didn’t have to charge those expenses to a credit card. Even if my overall liquid net worth hasn’t changed…

paragraphs.name: 06a9
paragraphs.text: Ups and downs for me. I’m so close to my e-fund goal, but had some medical expenses this month that will knock it down a bit in March.
For the first time ever though, I didn’t have to charge those expenses to a credit card. Even if my overall liquid net worth hasn’t changed much, I feel like I’m slowly breaking the cycle of…

ae4a55c9e038.title: Debt is less than last month (by a bit) and savings is mostly up, so I’m calling it a win.

paragraphs.name: 4e4d
paragraphs.text: Debt is less than last month (by a bit) and savings is mostly up, so I’m calling it a win. Deciding not to go on an overseas vacation also takes a little pressure off. Thinking I might be debt-free by this time next year? LOL, okay, probably not.

paragraphs.name: ee51
paragraphs.text: DEBT

virtuals.subtitle:
House/car repair fund Feb 1st: $0
Travel fund Feb 1st: $0

e424cb9c86ca.title: So I bought a new-to-me car last month (yay!)

content.subtitle:
House/car repair fund Feb 1st: $0
Travel fund Feb 1st: $0

paragraphs.text: So I bought a new-to-me car last month (yay!) but I let my emotions get the better of me and went over budget (booo) so I ended up throwing more of my discretionary savings into the car than planned. So the goal now is to replenish my house/car repair fund and travel fund to each be at least $1000.

virtuals.subtitle: Citibank Student Loan — end of January: $6,873, end of February: $6,690

a2769c0c733c.title: Thank all the gods for tax returns!

content.subtitle: Citibank Student Loan — end of January: $6,873, end of February: $6,690

paragraphs.name: f9d4
paragraphs.text: Thank all the gods for tax returns! We threw ours, plus some extra, at the portion of my spouse’s loans that were 4.5% interest. The remaining of my private loan and his student loan are both now 3.5%.
